title: This emotionally charged and zombie filled train is worth boarding
review:
Train To Busan (2016)
Rating: 4/5When you are about to watch a film in the zombie genre, you have two things in mind:
1) A lot many are going to die.
2) Zombies will provide us much gore.
Well "Train To Busan" has all that in plenty, but what it has which many zombie films lack is: Emotional depth. Throughout the film we are able to connect to each character. A fund manager, who is estranged from his wife, and fails to live up to his daughter's expectations; A strongly built man and his pregnant wife; a baseball player and a girl who loves him; a selfish as hell man; two old women who are sisters and many more form characters who are fighting for survival from zombies, in a train which is travelling to Busan. Will they survive?Director Yeon Sang-ho makes sure that while he shows the undead masses of bodies attacking the passengers of the train, we are connected to each of them. "Train to Busan" is a story of survival, compassion, sacrifice. It shows us how human beings act together to fight something bigger, which felt timely as we are in the midst of a pandemic ourselves. Then there's ones who are selfish. Take this scene as an example: The fund manager and all are trying to enter another compartment of the train, but the passengers of that compartment are paranoid that they might be infected, and they try to stop them from entering.While there's gore, but the film doesn't overdo that. There's some humour sprinkled, like the scene where the pregnant woman's husband asks the fund manager's daughter whether he's her real dad, as he initially didn't like her father. There's humour, but there's the seriousness which runs throughout the film. From the opening scene where a dead deer comes back to life, we know that things are about to become tense and the entire film is very tense but entertaining.There was a scene in the film which I found a bit absurd: the fund manager, the pregnant woman's husband and the baseball player deciding to fight their way to reach their people felt a odd choice that a person would make in such a situation and I wanted the film to make more impact. But, this emotionally charged and zombie filled train is worth boarding.

title: Fast moving claustrophobic, apocalyptic fun.
review: A movie about a distant father and his daughter who board a train along with a collection of other interesting characters all bound for Busan Meanwhile a zombie apocalypse is fast taking hold across the country. An infected passenger does the rest... Watching this movie, I couldn't help but draw visual comparisons to the type of infection seen in World War Z. There are indeed comparable stories in both movies, in the extended version of WWZ there is a strong Korean storyline suggesting that the infection could have originated somewhere in Korea. In TTB, the characters take centre stage and the apocalypse storyline has been compressed into this moving train. The characters are a clear representation of the best and worst of humanity and it's interesting to see them interact with their situations. It's almost like watching a case study on a zombie apocalypse... I wasn't a fan of the fate of some of the characters and the last minute death of the father seemed pointless but maybe my strong reaction was the intended reaction? Either way it's another cool Korean picture.

While the KTX is shooting towards Busan, the passenger's fight for their families and lives against the zombies - and each other.
Train to Busan does a great job of using the characters as a key tool in connecting the audience to the story. And this is where the emotions and the thrill go so effectively. Because whenever a character can bring the audience to be "The same team" has been achieved. "The same team" fully. title: Not a No brainer at all!
review: I've repeatedly heard some say that this movie is an absolute no brainer. I don't know if that's the majority of viewers that share the opinion, but I firmly disagree. This movie is such a refreshing zombie movie, the likes of which I've never seen in Zombie movies following the turn of the new millenium. The train provides an oppressive and anxiety inducing location, riddled with a heavy atmosphere that kept me tense. Even when they're not on the train the zombie spectacle is near impeccable and flawless. The zombies are great and seem to advance a lot of the things we got in the remake of Dawn of the Dead in 2003, with the charging and franticly running, contorting, non cautious, careless, relentless attitude. I never really got the appeal of the slow lumbering zombies, they just always felt Like they're a threat either as a horde or on accident. Don't get me wrong and misunderstand me saying that as faulting older zombie movies. I love them a whole lot as well. But Train to Busan zombies feel very menacing and infected. What do I mean by infected? Well it's the desire of the virus to just spread and propagate. It meerely compells victims to infect others instead of making them waste time unnecessarily by eating them. They only contract and move on to the next terrified witness. It just feels pretty realistic to be entirely honest. Just makes it seem like a next step that rabbies decided to take in evolution, so it just developed it's new dreadful properties. The characters are great as well. Most obviously our main characters, but also the other 10 or so this movie doesn't really struggle to juggle. Also there's a lot of great societal commentare scattered throughout. Recommended!!!

title: This film will make you sweat
review:
I thought I was bored and done with zombie films. Maybe not for all time, but for the foreseeable future. That was before I stumbled upon Train to Busan.
In this south Korean film from 2017 we follow a young father with a boring suit that has lost the spark for life. He boarders a train with his estranged daughter. During the start of the movie, we have these pretty common clues about animals and people staring to act weird. In many ways Train to Busan follows the zombie film playbook. But I think it goes furthers with creating very heartfelt stories. One of the biggest possibilities there is with the genre is too elaborate with the characters relationships to each other and especially to themselves in a time of horror.
They succeed in this area many times, not just with the dad and daughter who are perfectly portrayed. We have this young baseball player and his girlfriend as the cute couple. Then there is a pregnant couple who works as the comic relief when together. But the man in this couple is very skeptical about our protagonist father whereas the woman is bonding with the daughter. The chemistry is priceless between these characters and it makes the whole movie. At the same time, it is one of the better action movies in a long time and the suspense is world class. I was sweating almost the whole movie.

title: What A Film!

An absolute must watch for any fan of the genre!

title: It truly is the best zombie film in years.
review: Back in 2016, this film took not just it's homeland, but the world by storm, becoming one of the most internationally successful horror films of all time. The fact that it was able to make the zombie sub-genre fresh again is a testament enough to what a great film it is, and it achieves this through focusing on the very aspect that more recent American zombie films neglect. And that is the humanity and emotional core of an apocalyptic event. The film's bread and butter are it's exceptional cast, and thoughtful writing. This isn't a collection of faceless victims lined up for the biting, instead you'll grow to genuinely care for and root for these people. Underlying the entire film is a message of selflessness, as the story confronts the life of a selfish businessman who must learn to put others before himself if he wants to save his only daughter. Through this, the film critiques the callousness and corruption of business culture and capitalism, without ever beating the audience over the head. Thankfully, it's just as good a horror film as it is a humanist drama. The infected borrow liberally from the ravenous, fast-paced flesh-eaters in "World War Z", but without that film's reliance on atrocious CGI. Thus the moments in which crowds of hyper zombies chase the cast through confined spaces are truly intense. And those more suspenseful moments are only made stronger by the well-written characters. It's a true masterclass in how to make an effective, classic zombie film. One that American directors should take notice of. A real crowd-pleaser that offers drama, character, emotion and adrenaline-charged horror all in one.

title: Train to Busan
review: Train to Busan follows some pretty simple character arcs and story beats, but it's so much fun and so well crafted that it doesn't really matter.There are some predictable key plot points from the beginning. We know the father, stuck in business mode so often he can't even remember what gifts he's given his daughter over the years, will become more compassionate and present by the end. And we know that the evil characters will get theirs before the credits roll. But you know what? Those are the kind of story elements that can be very exciting in the right place. I want to see evil people get what they deserve. I want to see the business man become a good father. And I want to see the kind hearted child survive despite the selfish adults who surround her. These are moments that have me cheering the movie on even if I kind of already know where it's heading. It's like a warm blanket covered in zombie guts. I feel comfortable and disgusted all in one.Even with all this said, the movie is undeniably exciting. Action scenes are well shot and never feel too closed in to see what's happening. This is a very real concern for a movie that takes place predominantly on a train.There was an honest sense of loss when some characters died too. While most of them were underdeveloped there were a few that I felt like I really got to know in just under 2 hours. I think that was mostly due to some really great performances. It's all in their faces. Dong-seok Ma knocked it outta the park. He came off so smug at first but then evolves into your manly, trustworthy dad who doesn't know how to change his ringtone. It's so good. Su-an Kim is another standout. She is so quiet and reserved at the start, then as things continue to fall apart around her she has so much opportunity to show a range of emotions like anguish and fear. She killed it. This is a great child performance.The cg and make up effects are phenomenal. Some that were especially impressive were the zombie movements and the zombie deer in the opening. They sometimes looked a bit off but that only added to the charm.

title: One of the best movies of its genre ever released
review: Movie with zombies. I've seen a lot of movies of this kind, this is one of the top. Korean cinema, as always, invests a lot in emotion and is superior to everyone else. A film, slightly superior to which I consider only "I am Legend", which far exceeds the average of the genre. The train to Busan, a journey during which the zombie epidemic begins, and among the last passengers is an injured and infected. It's already too late after turning into a zombie. Where is it safest as the epidemic is underway? Inside the train on the move or outside? Survivors try as hard as they can to keep the zombies restricted in some wagons of the train, but for how long? An endless journey, where the destination is doubtful. Very good script development, building some characters, others with ideals, others altruistic and others extremely selfish. Who will finally manage to survive? Will there be justice? Very good performances, good direction and makeup, and a great ending, with a lot of emotion. Recommended to all fans of the genre, one of the best movies of its kind ever released.

title: Eh
review: Train to Busan is one of those biological disaster films that we have all no doubt revisited during the COVID-19 pandemic with a hyper-aware familiarity regarding the effects of a virus outbreak. I, however, found myself feeling the same unfazedness watching the film a second time as I did the first time. Train to Busan was branded as a horror movie, and yet I found its jumpscares and attempts at shock to be comical at best. With a main cast that felt like the amalgamation of the most generic character tropes possible, plus cheesy scriptwriting on par with the likes of Riverdale, it managed to place a sob story father-daughter relationship above the pressing conflict of a global apocalypse crisis. For example, in some scenes it is almost as if the imminent zombie wave in the background simply pauses while Gong Yoo's character and his daughter have a spontaneous heart-to-heart, or in other scenes the zombies blatantly go limp and allow themselves to be beaten to a pulp by Ma Dong Seok where they were previously rabid and ferocious.Beyond the awkward scene transitions and unrealistic fight scenes, the overall premise of a destructive virus outbreak turning humans into mutants was frankly delivered in the least creative way. Keeping the cast stuck in an enclosed space (a train) was probably one of the lowest hanging fruits in terms of a thriller-type setting. Having been an avid viewer of Korean film and TV, I like to think I can tell apart an original movie/series created for art's sake versus a movie made primarily for cheap entertainment or to garner tickets in the box office. This film, unfortunately, falls in the latter category. Painfully forced tearjerker scenes and the constant demise of everyone but the main character contribute to an overall tone of formulaic storytelling devoid of creative risks or surprises. Train to Busan is great fun if you're looking for surface-level entertainment on a Friday movie night. But it lacks any sort of original substance comparable to the previous film that lead actors Gong Yoo and Jung Yu Mi collaborated on, The Crucible (2011), which I would say is a much more worthwhile watch.

title: Train to Busan' might well be the only apocalyptic zombie action-fest to be openly inspired by Charles Dickens's immortal Christmas parable 'Scrooge'!
review: Director, Yeon Sang-Ho's almost absurdly locomotive 'Train to Busan' might well be the only apocalyptic zombie action-fest to be openly inspired by Charles Dickens's immortal Christmas parable 'Scrooge'! The doom-laden drama begins immediately after an allegedly benign chemical spill, along with massive civil unrest increasing exponentially there are wild & woolly reports of rioting across the country, and as the societal collapse swiftly spreads, various amusingly stock characters board the last train to darksvillle, along with one recently infected soul, who proceeds with laudable alacrity to scurrilously spread this especially vicious, bloodily viscous, universally eye-bleaching, zombie-making contagion! Unthinkingly aggressive, pack-like, dangerously nimble, this ferociously fleet-footed legion of relentlessly single-minded, flesh-craving savages makes for an especially unruly morass of terminally toxic humanity, and it will take all the available brawn, guile and collective humanity of our hastily organised zombie-resistance squad. A boisterous teenaged baseball team, an especially muscle-bound, Bolo Yeung-esque pugilist and his bulbously pregnant wife, a deliciously despotic, self-serving C.E.O, two immaculate, sit-com ready, octogenarian ladies plus the glacially aloof, hedge fund-manipulating estranged father of an implausibly cute, 'Spielbergian kid' desperately stave off this hellacious horde of hastily reanimated death, as their terror-beleaguered train wends its tumultuous 453 km journey to the hoped-for sanctuary of far flung, Busan. While the flighty film's non-stop, claustrophobic hysteria is frequently distracting, there's a singular sentimentality which felt incongruent; especially the existential, Dickensian emancipation of our handsome, young, estranged father protagonist, dramatically turning from callous, money-hungry 'Scrooge' to empathic, zombie-slaying super-dad! Another niggling irritant was the inevitable repetition of frequently frantic, door-fumblingly, 'oh-so narrow' escapes by our preternaturally plucky, carriage-bound protagonists, but, curiously, while only running at a lean 113 minutes, this celluloid exodus dragged on a wee bit, and could have richly benefited from some judicious editing, excising much of the saccharine sentimentality and enlivening the rather pedestrian script with additional fright-leavening flourishes of zesty repartee would have sped things along nicely, as more than once I could hear myself wearily ask the overwrought driver, 'are we were there yet?' 'Train to Busan' is a mixed bag o' rotten bones, while extraordinarily polished and well made, its momentary lapses of déjà vu, the timorous lack of practical gore FX and the film's grisly excesses of Spielbergian soul searching, perhaps, making this particular zombie apocalypse far more suitable entertainment for mainstream audiences than jaded, hardcore horror fans like me!

title: This is the best zombie film I've seen.
review: A very realistic portrayal of human emotion, human actions and scary as any nightmare, this film blows modern day zombie attempts right out of the water. Anyone wanting to make a zombie film should watch this for reference, rather than following the tired and overdone ridiculousness of boobs, sex and stupid people acting stupid, making stupid decisions and deserving to die.I find movies set in a running train intriguing. The aerial scenes were very well shot. The cinematography is spectacular n the editing crispy. The film is loaded with tension n mayhem throughout. The best character is the husband of the pregnant woman. One helluva selfless fella.This is the best zombie film I've seen. The effects are incredible and the acting great, too - especially Su-an Kim (who was also fantastic in Battleship Island). The film is insanely suspenseful at times as we follow a divorced father and his daughter trying to escape the zombie apocalypse. Unlike most zombie films, this film has depth and emotion, and beautiful music, too.I highly recommend this movie to everyone, 10/10.

title: Rate 10/10
review:
An overall excellent movie
A friend of mine recommended this movie. In his words, it would be "a kickass Korean zombie flick", so naturally i went into this movie expecting another generic, dumb, goofy zombie splatter film. Boy, was I in for a surprise!First of all, the acting is spot on. All the actors are doing a tremendously great job, but for me, little Soo-an Kim totally nails it in one of the best child actor performances I have ever seen. The zombie actors are also truly exceptional and they manage to spook you, without having to rely on heavy prosthetics and rotting flesh.Secondly, the cinematography is amazing. Although the whole story is taking place during daytime, the film manages to make you feel claustrophobic and constantly nervous without having to rely on cheap tricks such as jump scares or low lighting conditions. The cuts are seamless, the colours great and, though different from Hollywood standards, it is a generally really good looking movie.What really captured me though in this film was the drama. In this genre the characters are usually very generic and one dimensional. Though this flick is, at first, not so different in this aspect, as the story carries on we witness the shifting between the dynamics of the characters, we see their personalities evolve and change, we find out about their motives, their relationships and the depths they would go for their loved ones. I personally found myself very emotionally invested to the characters (which might be due to the great acting performances),I was actively routing for them and was really moved by the movie's finale.Don't get me wrong though. This is not some melodramatic drama flick. It is still an awesome zombie apocalypse movie. It is fast paced, it is action-packed, it is gory, it is tense and terrifying and it will keep you at the edge of your seat. It is also original, it doesn't play around and will surely satisfy even the hardcore fans of the genre. However, it is also a film you will remember for its awesome story and characters and for being an overall great movie. 10/10.

title: A near perfect zombie movie
review:
Some of the best films are from
Outside North America and this proves it. It's an almost perfect film from start to finish. It's non stop action from start to end. The characters are all well written and the acting is great. As zombie movies go this has to be one of the best zombie films ever made.

title: I loved it
review: It was such a great movie. It was funny yet sad and was a thriller but not that scary. I loved it.

title: Absolute masterpiece!
review: Man, South Korea has got it going on! I happened on this movie randomly, completely unaware of its fame and awards offshore. I watched it simply wondering what is a Korean zombie movie like because I had been long over the genre and especially The Walking Dead. What I watched was character development at its most refined fineness.Seok-woo starts as a typical father working much harder at his job than at his relationship with his daughter. The quickly unfolding and non-stop dangerous turn of events reveals what is most important to him, and shows he is not cold, that he does have a heart. The flashback at the end...as a father, I cried.Sang-hwa's crass, rude nature initially paints him as a selfish oaf who thinks he's better than everyone else. The quickly unfolding and non-stop dangerous turn of events reveals that he is quite the opposite. He is selfless, has a great sense of humor, and is the kind of person you'd prefer at your side if you were dealing with a zombie breakout.What director Sang-ho Yeon focuses on is not the action or the scares, but the characters. How they respond to the circumstances that challenge their ability to survive and care for others is like seeing a flower bloom. I feel like his whole point of the movie was to make us ask ourselves "Who are we truly?" We got bogged down with our careers. We take relationships for granted. We act hardcore in non threatening situations. But what happens when hysteria and danger overwhelm your atmosphere? Who do you care about most then? What's the absolute most important thing in your life? I'll tell you again...the ending. Ugh, I cried watching a zombie movie!

title: A Solid Seven

title: Train to Busan is arguably the best zombie apocalypse film of all-time!
review: If you enjoy reading my Spoiler-Free reviews, please follow my blog :)Zombie apocalypse is far from being a groundbreaking subgenre. The Walking Dead franchise is arguably the most popular show on Earth when it comes to portraying this supernatural future. World War Z and the Zombieland duology play that role in the movies' realm. However, all of these works fail to reach the always high expectations that come with a story set in a time like this. When people ask, "what's the best zombie apocalypse film ever?", one doesn't have a clear answer simply because there isn't an outstanding, mind-blowing, near-perfect flick. Well, at least not until 2016, the year of release of the best movie in the genre, Train to Busan.I genuinely feel sorry for everyone who refuses to watch foreign films for whatever reason. A different language and/or the display of subtitles shouldn't be enough to convince viewers to ignore so many unique works from all around the world. If someone dares to call themselves a "zombies fan" and has not watched Train to Busan yet, then "fan" is far from being the right description. This is South Korean cinema at its best. Everyone is 200% committed to their role, whether that is a stunt man or one of the protagonists. Yeon Sang-ho delivers a powerfully suspenseful, intense, epic, and most of all, heartbreaking story with the help of a phenomenal screenplay written by Park Joo-suk.When the only "negative" aspect that I can find is related to "maybe not-that-logical" specific actions performed by some characters, I know that I'm nitpicking a near-perfect movie. I struggle to find a single real issue with the entire film. In my opinion, the reason why the latter works so well is largely due to Park Joo-suk's script. Usually, people always think about the zombies first: how do they look? How do they act? Do they run wildly or stroll? Which new attributes or skills do these zombies have different from what we've seen until now? How did it all begin? Is there a cure? Granted, the zombies look cool, and Yeon Sang-ho is able to create impressive action sequences filled with maximum intensity and extreme tension. Entertainment-wise: top-notch.However, the action only works as well as it does due to the emotional bond that the viewer shares with the (non-infected) human characters. These are beautifully treated and developed in such a remarkable manner. There are easily five to six characters that the viewer ends up caring deeply about. Typically, at least half of this group is expendable in this type of film because some characters show no signs of intelligence or are just douchebags. In Train to Busan, every single character possesses likable traits, besides being directly connected to each other (father-daughter, young couple pregnant). The action scenes are filmed in incredible fashion, but it's the encompassing emotional aura that ultimately elevates them.It's really an emotionally devastating story. The viewer is placed in dozens of situations that require the hardest of choices from the main characters. The generic dilemma "do I save the person I care about or everyone else?" is taken to a whole other level with exceptional dialogues, filled with an excruciating amount of suspense, leaving me about to tear up on more than just a couple of times. Every character has a terrific, compelling arc. The main protagonist, Seok-woo (Gong Yoo), goes from being a despicable character, one that I wouldn't mind seeing killed in the first fifteen to twenty minutes, to a lovable father that only wants what's best for her daughter, protecting her at all costs during the apocalypse.This movie is packed with clever social commentary, relatable to this day (and even more during the current global pandemic). Yon-suk (Kim Eui-sung) represents everything that's wrong with our society. A selfish man who thinks he's more important than everyone else due to his class and whose job is more significant than his own family or friends, let alone strangers on a train. He also works as a "wake-up call" to our protagonist, as a "what if" version of Seok-woo's future if he continues to only focus on his job. Another character of great relevance is Sang-hwa (Ma Dong-seok), a father-to-be who ends up protecting Seok-woo's daughter when her father can't. His bravery and selflessness make him an instant audience favorite.Technically, it's genuinely a flawless film. From the outstanding zombie makeup to the mind-blowing stunt work, everything action-related serves as evidence to prove that South Korean cinema does action a thousand times better than conventional Hollywood. The level of intensity is ridiculous. Lee Hyung-deok's camera work is absolutely brilliant, moving through the train seamlessly, letting the viewer see and understand everything. Aided by excellent editing (Yang Jin-mo) and a phenomenal score (Jang Young-gyu), Yeon Sang-ho generates tension and suspense in a way that makes every single action sequence feel overwhelming, powerful, and even epic.A runtime close to the two-hour mark that flies by. The first act perfectly sets up the apocalypse to come with a surprisingly subtle build-up of the exponentially growing chaos. Then, the outbreak in the train which occupies most of the movie's duration. During this period, everything happens. From the nail-biting action sequences to the emotionally powerful moments of character decisions that make this film so shocking. Finally, a third act that left me floored, completely drained of emotions, not knowing exactly how to feel after it all ended. Despite a couple of sequences that I believe were exclusively executed in the way they were to offer an emotionally climactic moment, everything else feels impressively realistic.All in all, Train to Busan is arguably the best zombie apocalypse movie of all-time, at least, until the date of this review. The subgenre finds in Yeon Sang-ho's mind-blowing flick the masterpiece it deserves. From the exceptionally subtle build-up to the emotionally devastating final act, passing through the most vivid, suspenseful, tense depiction of a zombie outbreak ever put to screen, Park Joo-suk's screenplay is the reason why this film succeeds so well. A heartbreaking story featuring astonishingly well-developed characters, surrounded by a powerfully resonant social commentary, even more in the current days. Action-wise, it's South Korean cinema at its best: maximum intensity, phenomenal camera work, seamless editing, chill-inducing score, outstanding commitment from everyone involved, and a fantastic stunt team. Hollywood should learn from movies like this. I can't find a single flaw. It left me emotionally drained. If you're a fan of cinema, no matter the genre, this *must* be on your watchlist!Rating: A+

title: Must watch

title: Must watch!
review: Just finished watching this (and whilst a few years later to the party) I can honestly say that Train to Busan was perfect. 10/10 easy. Amazing. Intense. Realistic but also controls a very confronting zombie-esc story line. Action packed from 10 mins in and never lets go. Heart rate went through the roof and in a good way. Powerful storytelling and for a South Korean film, amazing. title: A FATHER-OFFSPRING RELATIONSHIP SAGA
review:
IT IS SAID THAT, BEFORE DEATH, YOUR MOST PRECIOUS MOMENT WOULD APPEAR IN FRONT OF US. WHAT IS YOUR MOST PRECIOUS MOMENT?A workaholic single father Seok-Woo (Gong Yoo) decided to give comfort his daughter Su-an (Kim Su-an) by visiting his ex-wife to Busan. They travelled to Busan by Train from Seoul which was, unfortunately, being victimised by a zombie apocalypse. Misfortune passengers became victim one by one. Someone's sister, someone's best friend, someone's daughter - indeed a pathetic situation. Seok- Woo and Sang-hwa (Ma Dong-seok) who also travelled with his pregnant wife Seong-kyeong (Jung Yu-mi) teamed up and tried to rescue as many passengers as they could. They faced lots of backlash not only from the zombies, but also from the living passengers as well due to shrewd and selfish behaviors of an evil-minded COO. The questions depict:
how many survivors would reach at Busan?
Would Su be able to see her mom?
Apart from the typical zombie horror genre, this movie shows the father-offspring relationship. The challenges that Seok - Woo encountered for his daughter and Sang-hwa for his upcoming child was precious. The movie perfectly displayed how an evil-minded top ranked official threw others into danger for the sake of his own safety even though those people wanted to save him! This movie also showed that being kind is always good and it would eventually come back to our life when we fall into utmost danger.
The acting of lead actors was great. The cinematography, the background music were also good.Train to Busan received Technical Award and Audience Choice Award for Most Popular Film in Blue Dragon Film Awards, 2016. It won Saturn Award 2017 in Best Horror Film category.

title: Epic to the max
review: I really rate this movie, it's refreshing to see such a great plot. The special effects are on another level, not cringeworthy, over the top like most Hollywood movies but very realistic and dramatic continuously throughout. I watched it thinking the next scene couldn't get any better only to be pleasantly surprised. It gets marked down because of many frustrating scenes where stupid choices and actions are made.

title: Fast-paced, Tension-filled, Best Zombie Movie
review: The action is fast-paced, non-stop, and this zombie movie is hands down one of the best! If you feel you've seen enough zombie movies, that they are all the same-give this one a try. It will not disappoint.

title: A wild ride
review: Take a simple concept and execute it perfectly - that's what this film does. Trapped on a trail full of zombies, a father fights to keep his daughter safe. The action is non stop, the acting is impressive, there's just the right amount of humor mixed in to ease the tension, and they manage to pull off a satisfying, touching ending. You won't regret watching this.

title: A zombie movie made me cry?
review: This movie is beyond incredible. As someone who hates zombie movies I went into this expecting a few cool action scenes and nothing more. But boy was I shocked and amazed by what I saw.This movie is the only zombie movie I've ever seen that actually brought me to tears more than once.The characters feel so real and their reactions are the cornerstone of this picture. The characters do not react in your typical "cool action movie" way, blowing zombies away at every turn. No, they are afraid, they are confused, they are selfish, they are human. They react in the way real people would react in this kind of situation. Some step up and go after zombies, some stay behind in fear for their lives, and some are putting others in danger to save their own skin. The reactions and characters are so diverse and I'm sure if I went in depth, each one could easily represent an aspect of human nature in survival situations.The setting is perfect and the things that happen are as realistic as a zombie movie can get. A huge moving train packed with zombies, no way to communicate with law enforcement, and no way to see what's happening in the outside world other than the TV. The only thing they can do, is survive until the train stops. This mix of danger and being left in the dark creates tension that leaves you on the edge of your seat, biting your nails, praying for the characters safety.Speaking of the character safety, in this movie, no one is safe. I won't go in depth with the more gruesome moments, but rest assured, nothing is off limits. You truly get the sense that anything could happen to these people at any time.The emotional parts of this movie are also an enormous strength. Since the characters all feel so real and so thought out, whenever one dies it feels like a stab in the heart. Even when an extra dies, the acting is so well done that instead of the typical "there goes another one" feeling typical of zombie movies you get a feeling of dread, that's constantly encroaching upon everyone involved.All in all, this movie is a perfect example of what a zombie movie can truly be, instead of the same action star schlock usually made. I encourage everyone to watch it at least once, to experience one of the best movies of all time.

title: Watch This!
review: This is more than a Zombie movie, This is a Masterpiece. I'm not saying this because it had gore, action or horror (it has all of those) I'm saying this because it had heart, Being from the usa I had to read the subtitles (Worth it) even still this movie made me care more about its characters than 90% percent of movies I have seen. This movie is not for the faint hearted however if you are 13 or older this is a must watch. This is on my personal top 10 movies. Watch this if possible!

title: Kinda Reminds Me Of Dead Rising. In Other Words, It's Insane!!!!!
review: I explicitly refer to Dead Rising in this instance because this film certainly gets so far out of hand when it comes to how many Zombies appear in here. I once saw this on Netflix and I was rather stunned at how impressively well-constructed the concept, plot, and character interactions turned out to be.It's as simple as a train ride to another part of Korea gone awry due to a Zombie Infestation. Most of the main characters do quite amazing work at staying alive. But as you'd expect, the majority end up dying eventually. Even the Main Protagonist ends up biting the dust towards the end of the film. It just goes to show that the Hidden Gem of some Underrated films is something totally different than the average Hollywood flick from the past to the present.

title: One of the best zombie movies I have seen.
review: I will put Train to Busan in the top zombie movies with Dawn of the dead (1978), 28 days later, Shawn of the dead and Dead Alive.Train to Busan was the first korean movie of the genre to get international recognition and success. Now with Parasite and Kingdom (Netflix original series) the korean movie industry is slowly starting to get the some attention.

title: South Korean Film Industry is the Next Big Thing!
review:
What differentiates "Train To Busan" from the rest is its immaculate character expansion & a profound piece of social commentary!
It may insinuate as another generic Zombie feature but trust me when I insist it's more than that.'Zombies' when you hear the word, you may be prodded by the never ending Resident Evil Franchise or some individual ventures by Hollywood studios! No matter how you got your firsthand experience with this type of Horror but I'm certain; you either have lots of fondness or a box full of disgust for these.
Zombie Movies have always gained traction from audiences'. Especially for its exaggerated Tonality. Albeit a tried & tested formula for box office success.
Yet most of the times makers get it totally wrong. They fixate so much on its extravaganza that they kinda forget about fundamental nuances.'Train To Busan' is evidently diverse in that case. Crafted by utmost maturity, this not only showcases usual tropes of the Sub Genre but also provides an underlying Socio Political attire which considerably indicates our Class partite society.
All of the characters in here, portrays distinctive thoughts and ideologies! They all come from different backgrounds resulting a versatile input into characterization aspect!
Their convincing acts had helped in that regard as well.
The storyline showed its efficacy in emotions! Teared me up good, not gonna lie.
Cinematography is great, for a South Korean production they undoubtedly nailed on the technical front.Except the Soundscore!I might be in the minority here, but the soundtrack didn't seem impressive to me at all! It felt highly incapable of generating fitting emotions in certain sequences!
I'm not saying it's trash; could have been miles better though!
Another negative would be its marginally stretched screenplay which caused its necessary momentum to break oftentimes.
It also had inconsistencies throughout the plot in terms of writing & detailing.
Bearing in mind possible spoilers, I'm staying away from any sort of explanation but you will understand.Still I can comprehend all of your affection for it! This is more than a mindless Zombie execution which had strong sentiments underneath unlike any iterations we might have watched previously.

title: i loved it - review for school pls ignore ty
review:
The end of the world. It sounds scary, right? When we think of the end of the world some people think of an asteroid hitting the earth. Others think we might be the reason for the end of the world. Another one would be zombies somehow become a real thing and we all eventually die, fun right? Train to Busan is a zombie thriller movie that follows Seok Woo, his daughter and other passengers trapped on a bullet train in Seoul, trying to survive while an outbreak of zombies is beginning. The movie has comedic moments to terrifying moments that have you at the edge of your seat with your heart racing, wondering what happens next. I did laugh many, many times. But I also cried quite a lot, for a good amount of time but I digress. While just meeting these characters, you just can't help but care and get a soft spot for certain ones. But there are a few where you just can't bring yourself to like, no matter what. I know I certainly couldn't like a few of them. But whether you like them or not, they still have you chewing on your fingernails, wondering what comes next.
As the title says, they are on a train heading towards Busan, South Korea. As most of you know, South Korea is known for its clean big cities, mostly polite citizens, and just all around a nice place. Well those once clean and advanced cities turn into these bloody, terrifying, and dangerous places. Even before all the chaos happened, the beautiful scenery was shown just before it became bloody. You can be enjoying a nice little moment while suddenly boom! The complete opposite is shown right in front of you. I will admit I got jumpscared quite a few times. And you can bet that it will be full of bloody, neck-biting monsters.
The very first thing that you see is a man driving and he suddenly runs into a deer. Unfortunately, the deer does die and he drives off after. But what he didn't see was the deer standing back up, after it had died. Now I won't describe every single scene so a little later we meet Seok-Woo who lives with his mother and daughter, Su-an. But he really doesn't spend that much time with them since he does spend most of his time working. On his way home he lets it be known that Su-an's birthday is the next day so he buys her a Wii, but what he forgets is that he had given her one for Children's Day, yeah yikes! At this point I know I didn't like him very much, you're just wondering how could he forget what he gave his daughter for Children's Day. But, Su-an is obviously used to her father not being the most attentive father out there, wants to go see her mother in Busan. She calls her mom to tell her and begs her dad to take her or to even just let her go on her own, which would be crazy! Given that Seok-Woo had messed up once again, he agreed to take her. At this point you do feel bad for Su-an, I know I did. While there is no doubt that she loves her dad and grandmother, she just wants to go see her mom. Who knows how often she sees her, and when it's your birthday you want to see both your parents, if it's possible. So they set out to Busan the next morning.
On their way to the station you get a glimpse of the city and the emergency vehicles headed to Seoul. Ignoring what's happening in Seoul, they arrive at the station. Here is where you meet the rest of the characters. Two elderly sisters, a pregnant married couple, an awful businessman, and a baseball team. Everything is fine and everyone gets on the train but since this is a zombie movie, at the very last moment a visibly ill woman gets on the train. I honestly don't know how she got in without anyone else seeing her. I would have left that train so fast! In the matter of a few minutes, the train gets full of these violent killing machines. As we can all expect, everyone freaks out and they run, but once they figure out what's happening we have a few of them fighting back for the safety of themselves and the other passengers. Personally, in this situation I can't say for certain what I would do but I like to think that I would help the people around and at the end that would hopefully lead them to help me back. You have to work together to survive this. But Seok-Woo does tell Su-an, "At a time like this, only watch out for yourself." At the time he definitely believed this but as time went on he knew that this isn't something he should be living by or teaching his daughter. There certainly was a time where I thought the same thing, every man for himself. But it has become clear to me, that is not the case, just like Seok-Woo. Now, obviously I won't spoil anything but the survivors only survived because of the sacrifices of others.. And the selfish ones met their demise because they didn't think of anyone else besides themselves.
Before I watched it I heard many people say that it was an amazing movie they would recommend it to me but I just never got to it. Now that I watched it, I really do regret not watching it sooner. I honestly expected it to be like any other cliche zombie movie or tv show out there. It really did not disappoint at all. I liked everything about it, the characters, the plot, the way it was filmed. With the way that it ended, I certainly did not expect it at all. But I actually really did like it. Now I would express myself more about how I feel about it but I would be spoiling it so that is all I will say about the ending. Another thing that I also found interesting was the way that the zombies moved. When you think of zombies you think of them as these slow but deadly monsters. You don't usually think of them as these super fast zombies, but then again these are fresh, newly turned zombies so you definitely have to keep that in mind while watching, I know I would forget that every once in a while. Also the way they moved was pretty different. They were like spasms. They would jerk around super fast. Once again, I would 100% recommend this movie to everyone. It may not be in English but that's not a good enough excuse to not watch it. We have to expand our experiences, and not limit them to just what we know. This Korean movie is incredible! It also left me wondering how well I would do in a situation like this one. How would you do? Would you survive or would the dead consume you.

title: BEST zombie film out there
review: This was easily, EASILY a 10/10. The film keeps you on your toes while also being incredibly heartfelt. Teared me up, which is rare for me. The action is solid. The characters are relatable, engaging, and believable. There's truly nothing bad to say about this film, except maybe that the ending is a bit of a downer, but if they ended it differently the film might not have had the same impact overall.

title: Excellent as most Korean productions.
review: By the time there are a lot of zombie movies out, and many of them fail to impress. And it is understandable, how can a movie be interesting if there are hundreds of movies about the same topic? Well, this movie, thankfully managed to impress and keep my eyes open every single second. As most Korean productions I have seen, special effects are top tier. The plot is not only about people running away from the zombies, but it tells a particular story a little bit different from what we are used to see on these movies. And, oppositely to what we are used to watch or expect on zombie movies, Train to Busan provides a soft moment that touched my heart and made my tear-up a little. This is not just another zombie movie, this is one that I really and highly recommend.

title: A lot of brains for a zombie flick
review: An emotional and terrifying dissection of what it is to be human. Social satire competes with melodrama and gore into this frenetic South Korean horror triumph. Movies about the undead have essentially been built on a foundation of fear of our fellow man. Yet TTB takes that a step further by building on the idea that, even in our darkest days, we need to look out for each other, and it is those who climb over the weak to save themselves who will suffer. Performances are outstanding all around, especially from the young Kim Su-an who incredibly makes every nightmarish scene seem utterly real.

title: Quality Zombie Flick
review: This was a good zombie movie. I was quite surprised. You end up caring for quite a few of the characters, and end up really despising some, ones that you wish die horrible deaths.A fairly simple and normal zombie plot. There's a virus or infection in Korea, people get bitten, turn into scary fast zombies (28 Days Later like), and mass chaotic fear breaks out. But with this story, it's mostly all on a train while trying to reach safety. This creates whole new level of anxiety as the options to survive are limited. I got vibes of Snowpiercer, but obviously with zombies.I enjoyed this film because it made sense, it was based in reality, nothing was over the top or exaggerated. As a zombie flick, I would very much recommend.

title: A perfect zombie movie
review: This movie is simply perfect, I can't find a single thing wrong with it, I highly recommend.

title: Too generic and stupid
review: Such a good film but my frustration is 10/10. Everyone made such dumb moves and decisions. Can't stand it. I've seen too many of these. Jesas.

title: Not good... BRILLIANT!
review:
From start to finish this film is near flawless. Great character build up with 1st class acting. A very scary story although zombie movies are now 10 a penny. This one certainly has that something special.
The acting by the little girl Su-an Kim was outstanding. What an emotional performance. I can't think of anything bad to say about this movie. If you think you have had enough of zombie movies watch this one. It's more than a cut above the rest.

title: Non stop action, fun, intelligent and hold on to your popcorn!
review:
As with all Parks movies this is simply great!
He's a fantastic Director and I cannot wait to see what he does next.

title: Decent zombie flick
review: Finally decided to watch this after years of seeing it highly rated in the genre's must see list - for sure what seem subpar dub/subtitles didn't help enjoying it, anyway it was a reasonable ride, with a passable plot, good zombie animations (the way they contort limbs was original and effective) and some nice characters to root for.. Ending was OK too.I wonder if the ones rating this an 8 or more have watched 28 Days Later, and if so how they've scored it, 12? For me it's a 6 1/2, but anyway if you're a fan I guess it won't disappoint.

This movie is different and will have you on the edge of your seat and get your feelings involved weather you like it or not. I think I cried about 3-4 times while watching this movie. The ending was also very good.

title: Well done with feeling!
review: We have waited to see this as it wasn't in English. We assumed it wouldn't be good with subtitles. We were so wrong! Excellent film not horrific like other movies, more of a thriller-drama. We loved it! Had the zombie thriller part with the human feeling as well. Watch it you won't be disappointed!

title: Aloha 'oe
review: If you like "zombie," films, as I do, you are sure to like this one. As in any drama you must identify and care about the characters. Plenty to care about here. Some original zombie action themes added to the enjoyment.

title: As far as Zombie movies go, it's got high production values, but low oringinality
review: I'm tempted to give "Train to Busan" only 5 stars, but I'm upping it to 6 due to it's extremely high production values. The best thing I can really say is that it's probably got more than enough blood and gore to keep zombie lovers happy. After reading so many really positive reviews, as soon as I noticed it was coming off Netflix, I rushed to watch it immediately. I really wish I hadn't bothered. "Train to Busan" is no more than a rehash of countless past films--everything from the "modern" zombies to the old-fashioned moral lessons. There's nothing original or thought-proving at all. It's basically a Hollywood popcorn feature emphasizing a tighter social and ethical code (like, say, how we idealize our own society of some decades ago). "Train to Busan" isn't bad, it just wasn't the phenomenal viewing experience I was expecting given the reviews or the shockingly strong films that sometimes come out of Korea. Frankly, I don't know what so many other people are thinking. For my tastes, although very slick, "The Train to Busan" was simply too long and too ordinary and too blatantly emotionally manipulative to be worthwhile or memorable.

title: The movie is realistically a 5.5
review: As a Korean or Asian zombie movie, I get it that it is a rare production done relative well. But in a larger scheme of things and comparing with all the zombie movies that have been done to death especially in Hollywood, this movie is AVERAGE. The zombies are unoriginal and so similar to World War Z, this might as well be a called World War Z: The Busan Contagion.That Korean cinema touch of inserting emo moments to every genre is just so cliche, worn out and in this case applied without much thoughts. Going through the day chased by flesh-eating zombies, your body is so flooded with stress and adrenaline, tears of sadness are the last thing that will flow out from you. And let's not get into the many many unrealistic and even unintentionally comical scenes.Movies above 7 in IMDB is usually worth a watch. This is not one of them. Those who rated this 10, please do yourselves a favour and watch more movies outside of Asia.

title: Awesome Zombie Flick

title: Best Zombie movie of all time!!

Highly recommended!I haven't seen Train to Busan 2 (Peninsula), but I can't wait how the story continues.

I absolutely love the young star who plays Su An. I have watched this numerous times, and it is suspenseful, and great every time! I recommended highly. As an added bonus, it is a Korean zombie movie, and right now, that is unusual!

title: Breaths life into a "dying" genre
review: Zombies have become so oversaturated in our culture. It has gotten to the point that zombies are just not scary anymore (thanks Walking Dead...). I just don't know if anyone could do anything new with this genre anymore until I watched "Train to Busan". The simple premise is that "A divorced father Seok-woo, his estranged daughter and other passengers become trapped on a speeding train during a zombie outbreak in South Korea".Let's talk what this movie does differently from previous zombie movies of the like. Firstly, the movie has the zombie stuff for the majority of the movie in an enclosed and cramped train. The claustrophobic nature of the train leads to some tense situations and even creative scenes that you wouldn't see in other zombie movies. For example, there is a scene where characters have to stealth by the infected in the dark and one where the characters have to punch there way from one cart to another. On that note, these action scenes are phenomenal. They are all thrilling to watch and always kept me on the edge of my seat. The zombies in this movie are very World War Z inspired but they are not just some mass of CGI. The zombies are phenomenal extras who manage to capture the essence of what a scary zombie should be through freaky body movements. Props should also be given for the makeup team as well because the zombies look as disgusting as one expects.Another element this movie does very well is the characters. Every main and supporting character stand out in different ways and each has vastly different personalities. The main character Seok-woo (Gong Yoo) is shown initially as a cynical workaholic who barely spends time with her daughter Su-an (Kim Su-an). Throughout the movie, he is selfishly just thinking about himself and his daughter but the character arc he goes through feels natural and believable. By the third act, you are rooting for him to succeed. The supporting characters in this movie are also great and each fully realized. My favourite has to be Sang-Hwa (Ma Dong-Seok) who is a tough and burly looking man who is trying to protect his pregnant wife. However, despite his demeanour, he is the one who puts himself at risk to help others, is the one who also provides the light-hearted comedy and is the one that pushes the development of the main character into a better person. He also has some of the best moments in the entire movie. Another stand out supporting character is Yon-suk (Kim Eui-Sung) a COO of some large business. He is absolutely the worst person in this movie as he is willing to sacrifice anyone just to survive and incite people to his cause. Major props to the actor for giving such a great performance in absolutely making me hate him. All the actors in this movie do a terrific job but I do have to give a mention to Kim Su-an who plays the daughter as child actors tend to be mostly a missed but Kim Su-an succeeds in the emotional moments and is a hit.While the story isn't something unique, the emotional moments and its social commentaries set it apart from something like World War Z. It's surprising but this movie explores a lot of the human nature of people. We see characters who want to do anything to survive, and others who will try to save others. The real main conflict that happens on the train is the clash between these two types of idealogy. We mostly watch our main character go from the survival idealogy to helping other mindset but the director also shows people who go from the opposite direction. There are also a lot of subtle commentaries sprinkled in this zombie movie tackling class warfare which is noticeable in the second viewing. The director also uses this to subvert expectations of characters like some who look shady or mean will be completely different. So this zombie movie is definitely not brainless" and is another reason it's so different from others. Sang-Hwa says in the movie "it's all about the sacrifices" and this is where the emotional core of the movie lies in, the main lead having to do whatever to get his daughter to Busan. I won't spoil anything but this movie really hits hard and it won't be surprising if you tear up at times. On top of these praises, the score by Jang Young-gyu is really good as well. The composer makes some sharp sounds that really elevate the creepiness of the zombies or intense scores for the cool action sequences.If I had to give this movie a flaw then I have to say that some of the characters do make dumb decisions near the end. It just feels like it was senseless and silly which can take some people out of the movie. Additionally, the final act is very green screen green and has a lot of noticeable CGI which can be a little distracting.Overall, Train to Busan is one of the best zombie movies to come in the last decade or so. The movie breathes new life into a "dying" genre and also tackles unique themes on classes and moral polarization. This is a definite must-watch for everyone, especially those who love zombie movies.

title: The bad reviews must be fake
review: Can't imagine someone giving this movie a score under 7, this should be one of the most unboring zombie movies I've ever seen. It's not about zombies, but humanity. People that are old enough to think should relate to the drama part easily and the message it's passing.The final 15 minutes was really emotional, and I didn't expect it to be so pronounced because I already got the "message" throughout the entire film before the last bite started. The movie would still be good even without the last part, and probably more balanced emotionally.

title: Excellent
review: Great Movie ,I really enjoyed it . review: This movie has taken the zombie apocalypse to a new level ! It has the Best fight and suspense scene and packs a lot of horror and exhilarating feel ! I recommend to watch this at least 2 or 3 times to properly enjoy this movie , Great Movie !!!!!

title: Close the door please!
review: I was going to write a review about some inconsistencies like unnecessary final "boss fight", different timing to turn into a zombie depending on the character, still getting shocked for seconds when a character see a zombie even after he saw 100 zombies before, freaking cold protagonist etc. And of course beautiful visuals , cgi and very good script.But then I read about some reviews and everyone is talking about that cool schoolgirl and I laughed so hard and still laughing. title: Very good for a horror film
review: I was completely kept thrilled throughout the 2 hours of watching this film. Almost all details are to be significant to some later events happening in the film. I was in utter and peaking disgust when it came to the scenes where the COO rat used other people's lives to save his. This movie did not just bring up intense actions, but it also implied some life lessons by portraying how selfishly some may behave when disasters occur. Totally recommend this film to everyone if you are not too scared of bloody scenes.

title: even a hater can eat this
review: If youve read the grumpy old mans reviews on zombie flicks, youll know that this is the lowest prioritized genre on his behalf. but this is a south korean film, therefore i had to view this, cause i admire korean films.as the title spells , its a train ride story , not an easy peasy one, rather a zombiyotic one, just to make a humble presentation to it. these zombies do not behave like the generic and stiff shoulder and paralysed stumbling legs spescies, its a juicy athletic, gymnastical variant of the kind, not friendly in daylight but calm in the dark.many train films do have the issue of the one location syndrome, but having seen train to busan i feel like ive been into every excisting loophole to everywhere during the 115 minutes of playtime.productionwise its darn magic from start to end, the intensity and speed of development are just staggering and breathtaking, the actors are familiar to us viewing lots of south korean action movies, but they ,and the stunter's are doing marvelous stuff on the silver screen. the cgi are spot on and the recipie simple, if your bitten its done.the score, which is a great component of the grumpy old mans filmexperience is just excellent and helps the plot and action amplified into something more. its a strait 10 with a recommend

review: Good action, plot zero. I wait second part/ one two threeeeee

title: Pretty good
review: I was sceptical at first when I saw this movie thinking it would be low budget and a tad boring but I was definitely wrong it is one of the very few zombie movies that is quite decent. Despite it being in a different language it's still amazing with all the gore and heart gripping moments in it.

title: Train to disaster
review:
*zombie about to bite a main character*Main character: but I'm the main characterZombie: ohh yeah rightttttMain character: yeahhhhZombie: understandable. Have a great day. 🤙
I mean come on, whenever it was the main character the zombies suddenly changes their behavior, slow when they are needed to be slow, fast when they're needed to fast. I'm not impressed with some of the acting, their reaction doesn't go with situation at hand. I mean some of them saw an actual zombie eating someone but their facial expression is as if that person is looking at a wall. And we didn't get an actual explanation as to how the virus got out in the first place, we were just told that it started from a biotech comp - not enough!Why were they at first mocking the lead character for being selfish eg for closing the door before the couple enter and the guy even said " I ThInk YoU ArE OwE Us aN aPoLoGy" like seriously?, I mean he was being selfish at an acceptable level considering their situation. Talking about selfish, there was this other guy he was self-centered almost to the point of being annoying. I believe he's the second bad guy right?
And why do people 'change' to zombie at different rate, one guy got bitten it took him only seconds to change but when it's the main characters they have a minute or two to say some few lines before they change.
What teen girl are the other reviewers talking about? I mean I didn't even notice anything worth mentioning there. I remembered she was there after seeing some of the reviews lol.
The movie is entertaining tho. it's non - stop action from beginning to end but that's just it.

title: Great Movie!
review: The movie was overall GREAT! The qualities of the movie were excellent! And to be honest there's no bad things I can say about the movie, All I can say is that it will get so emotional at the end. AND THATS WHY I LOVE IT!

title: Birthday Trip Turns Into Escaping To Busan
review: Dad is divorced and argues a bit with his ex on the phone. A little girl who is so cute and I love her perfect adorable voice wants to go to mom's for her birthday. Dad got her a gift she already has. The girl lives with her dad and grandma.The two of them board the train and we see various stereotypical types of people - the jocks, the cheerleader, the elderly sisters, the hurrying man in a suit, the conductor, stewards, etc.The girl from Wonder Girls comes on the train to the pleasant excitement of the boys in their baseball jackets and bats. She sits next to one of them.The little girl is innocent and does what is morally correct. Dad tells her that in these situations it's every man for himself but she still wants to be the nice girl. The little girl associates with the other passengers notably the pregnant woman and her husband and the two elderly women who she gives a seat to.The man points at his wife's belly and says, "I made that.". His wife gives him a look and he says it is true.Information is scattered, no one really knows what is really going on and the government isn't informing in detail. It is literally Darwin's theory about whomever is competent survives. Physical strength, quick running, attention is all tested in fighting and running from the zombies and not being bitten by one.The little main group comprises of Gong Yoo and his daughter, one elderly sister, the pregnant woman and her husband, and the cheerleader's crush. I love this group but they die off one by one, turning into zombies. We see a selfish man, the hurrying one who only cares about himself convince the crowd to block the door for our main group. The other elderly sister looks at her poor sister who has turned into a zombie and opens the door, letting the zombies bite everyone.The train track is blocked from a fallen train and fire. Gong Yoo, pregnant woman and the little girl escape on to another train. Gong Yoo is bitten by the selfish man and lets himself fall off the back of the train. The woman and girl walk through a tunnel where the military wait at the other end to see who comes through.

title: The little girl in this movie....
review: Is amazing. I usually don't like child actors too much, but she's incredible.

title: Not Worthy of the Hype
review: Maybe it's because of the excessive hype surrounding this supposedly groundbreaking zombie film but I was disappointed with this. This film feels like an unofficial World War Z remake in South Korea and not in a good way. There's really nothing in this film that separates it from others of its kind. It may be South Korean but it definitely feels like a typical Hollywood blockbuster.First big problem with the film are the unearned attempts at drama and tears. It's extremely melodramatic with too many attempts to touch your emotions and pull at the heartstrings, and it doesn't work because these characters are flat and disposable. They barely get any character development and are mostly just stock characters: the corrupt capitalist businessman, the dumb teenagers, the annoying kid, the hobo who speaks about the end of days, the damsel in distress, and the everyday man. They're the most one dimensional horror characters on the face of the earth who only exist to fight zombies and get eaten. I think it also says a lot that many of the positive reviews here only praise the cheerleader for being hot and not because she's a compelling character.Plus I found the "don't be selfish" aesop to be forced and poorly executed. It'd be one thing if the lead character had to learn over the course of the entire film to be more selfless and help other people as part of his path to become a better person but no, that little character arc is dropped in an instant. instead we get a hate sink character in the businessman who's presence beats us over the head with how selfishness is wrong by having him do increasingly despicable things just for the sake of it. He's not a character, just a token attempt at inserting forced and contrived conflict into the story.How to fix this? Cut down on the melodrama and remove the corrupt corporate executive and tramp characters. They're both annoying cliches (the homeless and filthy looking freak speaking about the end of days and the apocalypse has been done to death). Let the zombies be the villains for once in these movies instead of using that dumb "maybe humans are the real monsters" cliche.

title: Train to Busan is a must see!!
review:
There's just something so special about this movie. It's introduction to characters is done in a special way and at a good pace to make you almost feel connected to them. I, personally, didn't care if the zombies were slow or fast, or even if you'd consider them zombies. Their relentless speed kept me on edge the whole movie! It definitely displays the effects of "Selfishness vs Selflessness" and the "Collective vs the Few".
It's just such a beautiful movie that doesn't get the recognition it most definitely deserves!!Side Note: On the date of me writing this review, (8/16/2020), Train to Busan is on Netflix but if it's not when you view this, it's definitely worth the purchase. You won't regret it!

title: A best zombie movie.
review: Watched it in Korean language with English subtitle. Still it was great fun to watch this one. Nice direction and train made it fun to watch. Nice acting by.all the actors who were alive and who eventually became zombies. 😉

title: Overall great movie
review: I don't normally watch foreign movies, but this one I sat through from beginning to end. I knew I had to read subtitles throughout and I did not mind at all. This film had action all the way through and did not drag in the beginning. It had meaning to it as well. Highly recommended for those who love zombie movies.

title: Korean zombie horror told with skill, aplomb & utter poignancy
review: TRAIN TO BUSAN (2016) **** Yoo Gong, Yu-mi Jung, Dong-seok Ma, Su-an Kim, Eui-sung Kim, Woo-sik Choi, Sohee, Soo-jung Ye, Myung-shin Park, Gwi-hwa Choi. Relentless zombie horror film from Korean filmmaker Sang-ho Yeon (who co-scripted with Joo-Suk Park) where an outbreak occurs while a train is en route from Seoul to the titular town with an atypical cast of characters (harried father with daughter in tow; pregnant woman; baseball team; dickhead CEO) that is given flesh and blood turns by its talented cast (you root for everyone amidst the horrific carnage unfolding). The claustrophobia mixed with sudden dread is altogether palpable and incredibly poignant.

title: one of the best for a zombie disastrous film, good cinematography
review:
The 4-5 year kid acted fabulously, selfless caring characters are shown nicely, there is one selfish rich man also.
engaging film and the end it gets emotional when the father gets infected and dies.

title: Great Zombie Film
review: One of the best Zombie films since World War Z. This film is non-stop from the beginning to the end. Very intense and lots of blood. The acting and story telling is amazing. Worth the watch.

title: Too long
review:
Well, I've never liked any zombie movie, the reason they don't explain everything well. Now this movie has broken all records.
No explanation as how it started. Some infected transform in seconds, others take long time. Those two stupid granny sisters seemed like terrorists to me. Good guys or bad guys, all get killed, doesn't matter they're kind or helpful. I don't get how morality is encouraged here.

title: Worth Watching
review: I get the feeling that this is one of those 'must watch' films, even though I probably wouldn't set it apart from some of the really good films that I have seen in the past. Yet, in a way this film has a uniqueness that I really do appreciate, even though it is basically a zombie film. However, the scenes where the zombies are literally falling over each other in a massive horde really does make it pretty scary at times.Yet, a part of it also has a lot to do with the characters, and the various motives that each of them have. Further, considering that it is a zombie film, it is one of those 'last people standing' types, though you can pretty quickly work out who is going to remain standing at the end, namely because there seems to be this unwritten rule in films as to who is allowed to die, and who isn't.So, the film is about this Fund Manager who has to take his daughter to his ex-wife. They are in Soeul, and she is in Busan, which is basically the other side of Korea (and while the movie suggested that it was only an hour, I checked Google Maps and it suggests that the trip takes something like two-and-a-half hours). However, things really start going pear shaped as the train starts to take off. There are hints as to what is going on, but when it happens, it really happens thick and fast.I guess one of the key things about this film is how people react in moments of stress. Or moreso, how people act when the world starts collapsing around them. For instance, we have this struggle between doing the right thing for others, even though it might result in you suffering for it, or looking out for your own skin despite others suffering. The fact that the main character is confronted with this dilemma, and challenged throughout the film, is one of the things that really sets it apart.Another interesting thing to note is how being selfish can actually be a downfall in the end. For instance, in the scene where it is a choice between rescuing a couple of people, and saving themselves, their act to save themselves and let the others die results in all of them eventually dying. This also brings me to the point of how doors are used in this film. It may not seem like much, but in a way the question of survival really comes down to the use of doors, and whether you open them or not. Some are opened, others are broken down.I guess this is where the subtle references to class warfare come about, because the only reasons that there are classes is because there are doors, and these doors and closed and locked. Yet, in another sense this whole concept of class really only exists to keep the hordes at bay, and satisfied, since opening the door will result in you being overwhelmed. It is also interesting how in a group there always seems to be one who rises to the top, and then uses this position to further his own position, no doubt at the expense of others. It does show how fragile it really is, since all it takes is for one person to open the door, and everything comes crashing down.

title: Action, Heart, Drama and Morality in One Awesome Zombie Flick
review: This movie is my favorite zombie movie ever it had all the action you could possibly want in a train at a station and it felt like a mashed version of Snowpiercer mixed with World War Z. In a movie that had heart between the dad Seok-Woo and his daughter Su-an and their journey to Busan to go see his ex-wife and her mother for Su-an's birthday. On the train we get working-class man Sang-hwa and his pregnant wife Seong-kyeon. Sang-hwa was my favorite character in this movie and brought laughs and awesome action and strategy to a really scary movie. Yong-guk and his cheerleader girlfriend Jin-hee, elderly sisters In-gil and Jong-gil, and a homeless stowaway. All the actors and actresses were great and Seok-Woo went from unlikable loan lecher that only cares about himself into a really kind and awesome father. The ending gets me every-time, and the entire film your wondering is everybody going to die? Who is going to survive the cinematography was great, the directing great, action great, zombie violence great, this movie had everything.

title: Not only zombie
review:
Train to Busan is more than a zombie movie.
Also is about how important is a woman in our life. And about
selfishness and individual versus collective.
It is about the triumph of human life and the sacrifices necessary for human life to continue on earth.
It's easy to say that woman symbolized life in this film. In fact, the survivors are a pregnant woman and a little girl.
Because, life without women could not continue. This is the end that gives us hope for survival.
In ths movie, we are offered almost all the important representations that a woman can have, that of a wife, represented in the film by the pregnant woman (Seong-kyeong),
the one of the daughter represented in the movie by the little girl Soo-an, the one of the friend represented by the character Jin-hee, the two older sisters (possible grandparents)
In-gil and Jong-gil. Of these, only the first two survive because of the sacrifice that men from their lives, makes.
One of the two old sisters dies due to the selfishness of another interesting character Yon-suk, but the other sister sacrifices herself to avenge the death of her sister.
Jin-hee also dies because of Yon-suk and her boyfriend sacrifice, although he could very well have saved himself.
Yon-suk turns out to be a loner with only a mother waiting for him at home, hence his selfishness, to reach her at any cost, even treading on corpses.
The importance of women is often emphasized through the sacrifices made by those around, but especially because they are the foundation of our survival as a species. I didn't gave 10 because of some goofs, but really it's not so important.
This is a worth to watch movie!

title: Just More than amazing
